Award.AwardTitle: Ultrafast Nonlinear Microscopy in Nanowires and Nanowire Networks
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project, funded by the Chemical Structure Dynamics and Mechanisms Program of the Chemistry Division, Prof. John M. Papanikolas of the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill will combine pump-probe methodologies with nonlinear microscopy to investigate the charge carrier dynamics in one-dimensional nanostructures and networks on ultrafast time scales. The project will develop a new microscopy technique that will excite a nanostructure in one spatial location and probe the dynamics in another, on time scales ranging from femtoseconds to nanoseconds. Professor Papanikolas and his students will use this spatially-separated pump-probe microscope to visualize charge carrier migration through individual nanorods and networks. The project will focus primarily on nanowires with radial (i.e. core-shell) and axial heterojunctions with the goal of following carriers as the move through the structure, from one material to another.

This project will investigate how size and shape influence the flow of charge carriers (electrons and holes) through both individual nanostructures and collections of interconnected nanostructures. This issue is fundamentally important and critical to understanding many problems in nanoscience and nanotechnology. Variation in behavior from structure-to-structure, and even between different spatial locations within the same structure, is a hallmark of complexity and its presence poses a major challenge to those wishing to use nanoscale materials in a device applications. The project will also promote teaching, training, and learning in the context of a research program. Graduate, undergraduate and high school students will participate in this research. They will develop the technologically sophisticated instrumentation, apply those methods to the study of single nanostructures, and take part in the communication of their results at national meetings.

POR.DRECONTENT:
There is intense interest in semiconductor nanowires (NWs), particularly Si NWs, for use in a wide variety of nanotechnologies, including nanowire photovoltaics relevant to solar energy conversion, nanoelectronics and photonics. This project developed an optical microscope for studying the electronic dynamics of individual nanowires with combined spatial and temporal resolution.  A key feature of the microscope is its ability to excite a structure in one location and probe it in another, enabling the direct visualization of electron motion within a single nanostructure. This capability provides a unique view of the nanowire behavior that is difficult (or impossible) to obtain using conventional experimental methods, enabling charge carrier behavior to be correlated with specific structural features.  The microscope was used to image carrier motion in undoped Si NWs, providing a direct view of how electrons move in a nanoscale object. We also imaged the separation of charge in NWs encoded with an axial p-type/intrinsic/n-type junction (i.e. a p-n junction), a process that is central to the function of photovoltaic devices. By combining our experimental observations with large-scale computer simulation we were able to identify the physical forces that govern how charges move through nanowire structures. Subsequent experiments observed significant changes in the charge carrier behavior in bent NWs.  Experiments performed on flexible substrates show that the charge carrier behavior returns to normal when the NW is straightened, underscoring the reversible nature of the phenomena.  This observation indicates that the inhomogeneous strain on the silicon lattice introduced by bending deformation radically alters the electronic properties of the NW, which could be exploited in future nanotechnologies.  While the project advanced our understanding of nanoscale systems, it also contributed to the training of future scientists. Graduate student training was an important aspect of the research effort and a number graduate students, undergraduates and high school students participated in this work. They developed technologically sophisticated instrumentation and large scale computer models, and have applied them to the study of novel materials. They have aided with data collection and analysis, co-authored publications, and have presented their findings at national meetings.
